PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Focus is centred on Trump-Kim summit
content:
AUSTRALIA

Ausdrill (ASL AT)
- Co. stated that Yanfolila operations are running at full capacity and that works at Komana West have commenced. (Newswires)

Caltex (CTX AT)
- Co. guides H1 cost profit after tax outlook at between AUD 385mln-405mln. (Newswires)

OceanaGold (OGC AT)
- Co. intersects significant high-grade mineralisation on Martha and Empire veins at the Waihi mine. (Newswires)

Wesfarmers (WES AT)
- KKR’s purchase of Coles pubs business could be delayed by 3-4 months as it collates further information. (The Australian)

Virgin Australia (VAH AT)
- Co. CEO Boghetti will not renew contract beyond January 2020 and Co. will begin searching for his successor. (Newswires)

Westpac (WBC AT)
- Co. ends referral agreement with Prospa and plans to focus on more unsecured lending to SMEs. (AFR)

Energy
- WTI crude futures rose 0.6%. (Newswires)

JAPAN

Fanuc (6954 JT)
- Co. and Yaskawa Electric (6506 JT) continue to surpass European rivals in terms of profit margin, according to reports. (Newswires)

Mitsui Engineering & Shipbuilding (7003 JT)
- Co. will stop producing commercial ships at Chiba shipyard as the business continues to make losses amid tough competition. (Newswires)

Power
- Japan’s government called for power companies to cut their plutonium stockpiles following US request. (Newswires)

SOUTH KOREA

Daewoo Shipbuilding Marine & Engineering Co. (042660 KS)
- Co. CEO said the Co. could reach KRW 9.8tln in sales this year. (Yonhap)

Posco (005490 KS)
- Fitch raised Co. credit rating from BBB to BBB+; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS)
- Co. will begin mass production of foldable displays for smartphones. (Newswires)

Tech
- South Korea and Taiwan bourse operators cross-listed ETFs that track their joint index of IT firms as they seek to boost bilateral ties and support tech firms. (Yonhap)

Other News
- US President Trump tweeted that staff and representative meetings are going well with North Korea but added that it doesn't matter and that we will know soon whether or not a real deal, unlike those in the past, can happen. (Twitter/Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
UK

UK government is working on a Brexit bill compromise according to ministers. In related news, UK Brexit Secretary Davis is said to back deal to buy-off Tory rebels ahead of the EU Withdrawal Bill vote in the UK's lower house, while there were also comments from UK solicitor general Baker that the government is discussing with lawmakers the replacement of an Upper House amendment on EU's customs union and that it is appropriate to have a customs arrangement with the EU. (Newswires)

Irish PM Varadkar said there is a small chance of no Brexit deal by October and that Article 50 could be extended for more Brexit talks. (Newswires)

UK Industrial Output MM (Apr) -0.8% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires)
UK Industrial Output YY (Apr) 1.8% vs. Exp. 2.7% (Prev. 2.9%)
UK Manufacturing Output MM (Apr) -1.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. -0.1%)
UK Manufacturing Output YY (Apr) 1.4% vs. Exp. 2.9% (Prev. 2.9%)
UK Goods Trade Balance GBP (Apr) -14.03B vs. Exp. -11.25B (Prev. -12.29B, Rev. -12.0B)
 

EU

German Chancellor Merkel agreed with the US to review trade ties and existing ties, while she noted it is clear the EU will respond to US tariffs on steel and aluminium. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

Saudi Arabia are said to announce they are producing more than 10mln BPD, according to sources. (Newswires)

Iraq oil minister says to expect 'a tough but not very tough' OPEC meeting on June 22nd, adding that Iraq will decide to boost output if there is consensus among other members


GEOPOLITICAL

US issued further sanctions on Russia related to the cyber activity 2017 law which is aimed at 5 Russian entities and 3 Russian individuals. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

In the aftermath of the G7 fallout, ES gapped lower on the reopen, though gradually ground its way up, seeing highs above 2790, though slipped beneath that level in the closing minutes of cash trading. Goldman Sachs tech analysts said 2823-24 is the next level to watch on the upside, and monitor for signs of exhaustion – if 2824 holds, further upside could be seen, otherwise we may come back to visit 2742. In stock specifics, Sempra Energy (SRE) was a top performer on Monday, following activist Elliott Management’s urging the company to reshuffle its board and to establish a review committee. On the other end of the scale, Pacific Gas & Electric (PCG) pressuring the SPX today following a report from state officials claiming the fires last year which killed 46 people were sparked by its power lines. Attention tomorrow will be on AT&T’s (T) merger with Time Warner (TWX), with a judge expect to deliver his ruling at the cash close; both companies are trading higher today, and the telecom sector was also boosted today ahead of the decision. CNBC notes the spin off effect from this decision may flow into other companies with M&A hopes as, such as Disney’s (DIS) offer to buy Fox (FOXA), CVS (CVS) offer for Aetna (AET) and T-Mobile’s (TMUS) proposed merger with Sprint (S). Later, it was reported that Comcast (CMCSA) will formalize its all-cash bid for Twenty-First Century Fox’s (FOXA) assets on Wednesday if AT&T's (T) bid for Time Warner (TWX) is approved tomorrow, sources tell CNBC. SPX +0.11%, NDX +0.22%, DJI +0.03%.

Treasury yields were higher on Monday ahead of the FOMC’s policy meeting on Wednesday, where a 25bps is priced with virtual certainty. The complex was helped by continuing deflating of the political risk premium in Europe, analysts said, where over the weekend, the Italian finance minister said that the country has no intention of leaving the Euro area, helping the Bund/BTP spread to narrow. The US Treasury auctioned $32bln in 3yr notes, tailing by 0.1, and saw the same high yield as May’s auctions. Indirect participation was strong, taking down the largest share since January. Directs participation was below recent averages, while dealer take down was slightly above recent averages. The 10yr note auction stopped-through the screens by 0.3bps with cover the highest since January. Indirect participation was, however, well below the six month average, seeing direct participation almost double versus the previous month, though dealer participation was in line with recent averages. US 10YR T-notes futures (Sep 2018) at 5 ticks lower at 119-14.

US MARKET WRAP 11 June 2018: Markets shrug-off G7 fallout; Trump/Kim to meet
content:
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, DXY up, Crude up
* REAR-VIEW: Saudi and Russia raise oil output; market shrugs-off continued negative rhetoric from G7 fallout.
* AHEAD: Trump/Kim to meet at 2am BST, press conference 1300 BST on Tuesday; US CPI; UK jobs, Brexit vote; German ZEW.

* TRADE: G7 participants continued to talk-down US President Donald Trump, though there was little by way of new information; the general takeaway has been that global relations have soured, though markets looked through the hyperbole to trade with a firm risk tone on Monday. In specific news, German Chancellor Merkel has reportedly agreed with the US to review trade ties and existing ties, noting it is clear the EU will respond to US tariffs on steel and aluminium. UK PM May said participants should try a=nd encourage the WTO to make gloval trade war rules work more effectively, and also added that she expects to negotiate a good trade deal with the EU. Mexican Economy Minister Guajardo said NAFTA members will engage again in early July to craft an agreement which is feasible and added there is a high chance an agreement on NAFTA will be made.

* SPX +0.11%, NDX +0.22%, DJI +0.03%. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +0.4%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.8%, Energy: +0.4%, Financials: -0.3%, Health Care: +0.1%, Industrials: +0.2%, Materials: +0.1%, Telecoms: +0.7%, Tech: 0.0%, Utilities: -0.3%. In the aftermath of the G7 fallout, ES gapped lower on the reopen, though gradually ground its way up, seeing highs above 2790, though slipped beneath that level in the closing minutes of cash trading. Goldman Sachs tech analysts say 2823-24 is the next level to watch on the upside, and monitor for signs of exhaustion – if 2824 holds, further upside could be seen, otherwise we may come back to visit 2742.

* Stock Specifics: Sempra Energy (SRE) was a top performer on Monday, following activist Elliott Management’s urging the company to reshuffle its board and to establish a review committee. On the other end of the scale, Pacific Gas & Electric (PCG) pressuring the SPX today following a report from state officials claiming the fires last year which killed 46 people were sparked by its power lines. Attention tomorrow will be on AT&T’s (T) merger with Time Warner (TWX), with a judge expect to deliver his ruling at the cash close; both companies are trading higher today, and the telecom sector was also boosted today ahead of the decision. CNBC notes the spin off effect from this decision may flow into other companies with M&A hopes as, such as Disney’s (DIS) offer to buy Fox (FOXA), CVS (CVS) offer for Aetna (AET) and T-Mobile’s (TMUS) proposed merger with Sprint (S). Later, it was reported that Comcast (CMCSA) will formalize its all-cash bid for Twenty-First Century Fox’s (FOXA) assets on Wednesday if AT&T's (T) bid for Time Warner (TWX) is approved tomorrow, sources tell CNBC.

* M&A: Envision Healthcare (EVHC) confirmed it is to be acquired by KKR (KKR) for USD 46/shr, for a deal totalling USD 9.9bln including debt. USG (USG) is to be purchased by Knauf for USD 44/shr worth roughly USD 7bln, and La Salle Hotel (LHO) received a higher offer from Pebblebrook for USD 37.80/shr. Elsewhere, a group of shareholders in Takeda Pharmaceuticals are trying to gain support to block the USD 62bln acquisition of Shire (SHPG), at an extraordinary general meeting. Reports also stated that Boston Scientific (BSX) received a takeover approach from Stryker (SYK) which would create a medical device giant worth more than USD 110bln, according to people familiar with the matter. 

* WTI FUTURES (N8) SETTLE UP 36 CENTS AT $66.10/BBL; BRENT (Q8) SETTLES UNCHANGED AT $76.46/BBL. Oil ticked up on Monday, shrugging-off rising US drilling activity (Baker Hughes on Friday reported active oil rigs were up by one last week), as well as reported increasing output in Russia and Saudi Arabia; Interfax reported that Russian output jumped to 11.1mln BPD (versus just under 11mln last month). Saudi Arabia, meanwhile, raised daily output to above 10mln BPD to the highest levels since last October; analysts at PVM said this bears the hallmarks of an OPEC+ shift in output policy. Later, Iraq’s oil minister said that the country will decide on an output increase if OPEC takes such a course at its meeting on the 22 June meeting in Vienna (OPEC is to consider short-term and long-term market stability at the meeting in Vienna, according to the Qatari oil minister). Elsewhere, the UAE energy minister denied that the US had made a request to OPEC to lift output by 1mln bbls; journalists noted that their sources pieces in fact used language to suggest that the requests were made to individual countries, not the cartel officially. Elsewhere, Argus reported OPEC oil production remained close to a three-year low in May at 31.76mln BPD. There was a bounce in oil prices after Genscape released its Cushing stocks forecast to subscribers at 1000 EDT, which led to some speculating that it was projecting a sharp draw in this week’s data; the latest Reuters poll finds analysts expect headline crude stocks to draw by 2.9mln this week, distillates are seen drawing by 0.1mln, and gasoline is expected to post a small build of 0.1mln.

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (SEP 2018) AT 5 ticks lower at 119-14. Treasury yields were higher on Monday ahead of the FOMC’s policy meeting on Wednesday, where a 25bps is priced with virtual certainty. The complex was helped by continuing deflating of the political risk premium in Europe, analysts said, where over the weekend, the Italian finance minister said that the country has no intention of leaving the Euro area, helping the Bund/BTP spread to narrow. The US Treasury auctioned $32bln in 3yr notes, tailing by 0.1, and saw the same high yield as May’s auctions. Indirect participation was strong, taking down the largest share since January. Directs participation was below recent averages, while dealer take down was slightly above recent averages. The 10yr note auction stopped-through the screens by 0.3bps with cover the highest since January. Indirect participation was, however, well below the six month average, seeing direct participation almost double versus the previous month, though dealer participation was in line with recent averages.

* USD: The broad Dollar was pretty mixed in the aftermath of the weekend G-7 gathering that ended in discord and President Trump disassociating the US from the official communique. The DXY is flat, however, basing above 93.50 ahead of CPI data and the FOMC this week.

* EUR: Political tension continues to ease in the bloc ahead of what market participants believe will be a hawkish update from the ECB this week (following comments from the normally dovish Praet last week, in addition to other hawkish commentary from other policymakers) when it discusses the exit from its QE programme. After gapping up on the Sunday reopen, action has been horizontal, with support above 1.1750, and some desks are talking about finding entries targeting upside this week.

* JPY: Hopes of a constructive outcome between at the summit with North Korea, as well as easing political tensions in Europe have weakened demand for the yen, with traders shrugging off the post-G7 meeting contentious rhetoric between the US and the rest of the group.

* CAD: USDCAD gapped up on the Sunday reopen as the wa of words between Trump and Trudeau took its toll. However, risk sentiment was constructive on Monday, and commodities were bid, helping USDCAD fall back beneath 1.30 consolidating around 1.2980. Note, a prominent US bank is eyeing 1.3125 after establishing a long at 1.2965.

* GBP: Another major underperformer ahead of Tuesday’s key Brexit withdrawal bill debate and vote, as a string of UK data releases missed consensus by a hefty margin to keep already lowly BoE rate hike expectations depressed. Cable reversed sharply from around 1.3440 and a few pips off its 30 DMA (1.3444) to take out short term technical support at the 200 HMA (1.3363) and briefly dip below 1.3350, while EURGBP cleared 0.8800, but held just below the 200 DMA (0.8836). Ahead of tomorrow’s key vote in the Commons, PM May told Conservative MPs to back her or risk undermining EU talks; the general flow of news suggests that May has been successful in persuading the influential 1922 Committee to vote with her, although the situation naturally remains fluid. In Brexit news: Irish PM Varadkar says there is a small chance of no Brexit deal by October, and that Article 50 could be extended for more Brexit talks. Meanwhile, there was further newsflow suggesting that the EU was not on board with May’s time-limited backstop proposal.

* AUD: Registered gains vs its US counterpart on wider global risk appetite (again outside of the quarrel in Quebec). Some desks suggest risk sentiment around central banks will be the swaying factor for the Aussie this week, given that it remains relatively shielded from Trade Wars. 0.7590-0.7600 is seen as support, targeting congestion between 0.7620-30.

* CHF: Relatively rangebound vs the USD around 0.9850 and EUR above 1.1600 in wake of the Swiss verdict to keep the status quo for banks and vote against the Vollgeld proposals.

* COMING UP: Trump/Kim Summit: US President Trump is set to meet North Korean Supreme Leader Kim in Singapore on Tuesday. Progress has been more rapid than expected, according to the White House, and Trump will meet with Kim for a one-to-one meeting at 9am local time in Singapore (9pm EDT), with a press conference scheduled for 8pm local time (8am EDT). The ultimate aim of the discussions for Trump is for North Korea to denuclearise but the likelihood of a firm agreement and treaty signed on Tuesday is slim to none. Barclays say the best-case scenario for the talks is that negotiators outline a multi-year process for the complete, verifiable, and irreversible dismantlement of the North Korean nuclear program; halt testing of ballistic missiles; and lay out potential enforcement mechanisms.

* COMING UP: EU Withdrawal Bill vote: On Tuesday, the UK Parliament is holding a mammoth session of debate and votes on the Lords amendments to the Brexit Withdrawal Bill. The session is expected to last 12 hours after the government was defeated 15 times in the House of Lords on issues ranging from environmental protection standards to the Customs Union, Irish Border and the end date for Brexit. After losing seats in the 2017 General Election, UK PM May’s working majority in parliament stands at just 13 seats, including the support of the 10 DUP MPs that have agreed to back the government on key issues.

subject: UBS Weekly FX Flows: EUR sold for a 10th week
content:
• EURUSD: EURUSD  was  marginally  sold  as  strong  selling  by  hedge  funds  outweighed buying by all other client groups.
  • USDJPY,  EURJPY:  JPY  saw  inflows  vs  USD  as  buying  by  asset  managers  and  private  clients  exceeded  selling  by  hedge  funds  and  corporates.  EURJPY  was  net  sold  for  a  fourth  straight  week,  led  by  hedge  funds  and  asset  managers  while  corporate  and  private clients showed limited directionality.
  • GBPUSD,  EURGBP:  GBPUSD  was  net  bought,  as  all  client  groups  registered  inflows,  led by asset managers. GBP recorded strong inflows vs EUR, from all client groups and led by asset managers.
  • EURCHF,  USDCHF:  EURCHF  was  bought  for  a  fifth  straight  week,  as  outflows  from  asset  managers  were  more  than  offset  by  inflows  from  all  other  clients.  USDCHF  saw  strong outflows, as all client groups sold the pair.
  • AUDUSD,  NZDUSD,  and  USDCAD:  AUDUSD saw  strong  inflows  for  a  fifth  week,  predominantly driven by hedge funds' buying interest. NZDUSD was net bought, mainly led  by  inflows  from  asset  managers  and  hedge  funds,  while  corporates  and  private  clients  were  marginal  sellers.  USDCAD  saw  outflows,  as  asset  managers  and  private  clients selling outweighed buying from hedge funds and corporate clients.
  • EURSEK, EURNOK, USDSEK, and USDNOK: EURSEK saw marginal outflows as hedge funds'  selling  interest  slightly  exceeded  buying  interest  from  asset  managers.  EURNOK was net bought as inflows from asset managers and hedge funds outweighed outflows from  corporates.  USDSEK  registered  inflows  as  buying  by  hedge  funds  exceeds  selling  by  asset  managers,  while  corporate  and  private  clients  showed  limited  directionality. NOK registered inflows vs USD, led almost entirely by hedge funds.

analysis_details: Oil ticked up on Monday, shrugging-off rising US drilling activity (Baker Hughes on Friday reported active oil rigs were up by one last week), as well as reported increasing output in Russia and Saudi Arabia; Interfax reported that Russian output jumped to 11.1mln BPD (versus just under 11mln last month). Saudi Arabia, meanwhile, raised daily output to above 10mln BPD to the highest levels since last October; analysts at PVM said this bears the hallmarks of an OPEC+ shift in output policy. Later, Iraq’s oil minister said that the country will decide on an output increase if OPEC takes such a course at its meeting on the 22 June meeting in Vienna (OPEC is to consider short-term and long-term market stability at the meeting in Vienna, according to the Qatari oil minister). Elsewhere, the UAE energy minister denied that the US had made a request to OPEC to lift output by 1mln bbls; journalists noted that their sources pieces in fact used language to suggest that the requests were made to individual countries, not the cartel officially. Elsewhere, Argus reported OPEC oil production remained close to a three-year low in May at 31.76mln BPD. There was a bounce in oil prices after Genscape released its Cushing stocks forecast to subscribers at 1000 EDT, which led to some speculating that it was projecting a sharp draw in this week’s data; the latest Reuters poll finds analysts expect headline crude stocks to draw by 2.9mln this week, distillates are seen drawing by 0.1mln, and gasoline is expected to post a small build of 0.1mln.

subject: AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 32bln of 3y notes and USD 22bln of 10y notes
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

3y notes

The US Treasury will issue $68bln at auction this week ($32bln of new 3-year paper on Monday, as well as $22bln in a 10-year reopening on Monday, and $14bln in a 30-year reopening on Tuesday). With $24bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, the Treasury will raise a net $44bln in new money. And looking ahead, for the week beginning 25 June, there will be approximately $82bln of redemptions and around $8bln of coupon payments; over the next four weeks, there is around $115bln of cash flows, according to UBS. Recent three-year auctions have been encouraging; although the last auction saw a 0.1bps tail, the average over the last three and six auctions has been on the screws. Also at the last auction, the high yield came in at 2.664%, the highest since May 2007; dealers were left with the largest proportion of the issuance at 42.2%, well above the 6-auction average. Directs were awarded 12.3% and indirect 14.6%, the smallest portion since July 2016. Traders will, however, be cautious of the FOMC monetary policy decision on Wednesday, where it is expected to hike the FFR target by 25bps. The bidding deadline for the auction is 1630BST/1130EDT with results expected shortly after.

10y notes

Auctions in the 10-year sector have been mixed, as of late; averages over the last three auctions and six auctions has seen a tail of 0.2bps – the last 10-year auction to stop through was in January (stopped through by 0.5bps). Analysts at TD Securities expect the 10-year auction to go well if yields are hovering at 3% before the auction. The bidding deadline for the auction is 1800BST/1300EDT with results expected shortly after.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Loonie lurches post-G7 and Pound plunges post-UK data
content:
CAD

The big loser as relations between Canada and the US deteriorated markedly after President Trump launched a twitter tirade in response to comments from PM Trudeau declaring tariff proposals an insult. The Loonie tested 1.3000 lows vs the Usd before finding some solace amidst a broad upturn in risk sentiment, but then weakened further to hit circa 1.3025 at worst. Note, a prominent US bank is eyeing 1.3125 after establishing a long at 1.2965.

GBP

Another major underperformer ahead of Tuesday’s key Brexit withdrawal bill debate and vote, as a string of UK data releases missed consensus by a hefty margin to keep already lowly BoE rate hike expectations depressed. Cable reversed sharply from around 1.3440 and a few pips off its 30 DMA (1.3444) to take out short term technical support at the 200 HMA (1.3363) and briefly dip below 1.3350, while Eur/Gbp cleared 0.8800, but held just below the 200 DMA (0.8836).

JPY

A victim of non-G7 factors that sapped the currency’s safe-haven allure, as Italy’s new Economy Minister said the coalition is unified in its intentions to remain a Eurozone member and hopes for a successful, if not productive US-NK summit were boosted by reports from US Secretary of State Pompeo. Usd/Jpy climbed above 110.00 and Eur/Jpy crossed 130.00 amidst stops and chart-related buying, but the headline pair was capped ahead of its 200DMA (110.18) and the latter met offers at the big figure.

EUR

Firm and a G10 front-runner all day as the single currency kept tabs of the 1.1800 handle vs the Usd, and benefited to the detriment of the Pound and Jpy as noted above.

AUD/NZD

Both registering gains vs their US counterpart on wider global risk appetite (again outside of the quarrel in Quebec), with the respective pairs above 0.7600 and 0.7000.

CHF

Relatively rangebound vs the Usd around 0.9850 and Eur above 1.1600 in wake of the Swiss verdict to keep the status quo for banks and vote against the Vollgeld proposals.

SCANDI/EM

Off worst levels, but the Nok was deflated by soft Norwegian CPI metrics, while the Peso was rattled by NAFTA and general trade concerns again and the Try weakened on a rise in demand at the latest daily swap auction that overshadowed better than expected Turkish Q1 GDP data.

content: The DXY has marginally extended the topside of its overnight range to 93.600+ levels amidst Usd gains across the board, but especially vs the Cad, Gbp and Jpy that are testing key levels again – Loonie support around 1.3000, Cable through its 200 HMA circa 1.3363 and now just above 1.3350, and Usd/Jpy 110.00. Not much in the way of new drivers, but the Cad is still mulling the war of words between Trump and Trudeau, the Pound is reeling further in wake of abject UK data and the Jpy remains off initial post-G7 peaks along with its safe-haven ally the Chf. Even the relatively firm Eur has lost grip of 1.1800, while Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd are both looking a bit less comfortable above respective round numbers at 0.7600 and 0.7000.

Daily US Opening News: 11th June 2018 - Now available in the Research Suite
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European bourses higher ahead of Trump/Kim summit and as Italy reiterates plans to stay in the Eurozone
  • Sterling slides as industrial production has biggest monthly fall since October 2012 and trade deficit widens
  • Looking ahead, highlights include 3- and 10-year note auctions from the US
  •  

ASIA-PAC

Asian markets began the week somewhat cautious ahead of the upcoming key risk events including the summit between US and North Korea tomorrow, as well as the FOMC and ECB policy meetings later this week. Furthermore, a market closure in Australia and the G7 fall out in which Trump refused to endorse the communique and criticized Canadian PM Trudeau as being dishonest and weak, also added to the tentative tone. Nevertheless, the Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) and KOSPI (+0.8%) were positive as focus turned towards the upcoming historical Trump-Kim summit. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were mixed with underperformance in mainland China after inaction by the PBoC led to a liquidity drain and as participants digested mixed inflation data. Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat amid the tentative tone in the region and a lack of Rinban announcement by the BoJ.

Chinese CPI (May) M/M -0.2% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. -0.2%). (Newswires)
Chinese CPI (May) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.8%)
Chinese PPI (May) Y/Y 4.1% vs. Exp. 3.9% (Prev. 3.4%)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 20bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4064 (Prev. 6.4003)

G7/TRADE

G7 official communique - which was backed by all countries apart from the US - acknowledged free, fair and mutually beneficial trade was a vital engine for growth and jobs, while the countries will strive to lower tariff barriers and subsidies, as well as continue fighting protectionism. (Newswires)

US President Trump refused to endorse the G7 communique which he stated was due to false statements made by Canadian PM Trudeau who he criticized as being dishonest and weak, while he also suggested the US is looking at tariffs on autos flooding the market. This was in response to comments from Canadian PM Trudeau that Canada would impose retaliatory tariffs against US and warned that Canada would not be pushed around. (Twitter/Newswires)

DATA

UK Industrial Output YY (Apr) 1.8% vs. Exp. 2.7% (Prev. 2.9%). (Newswires)

UK Manufacturing Output YY (Apr) 1.4% vs. Exp. 2.9% (Prev. 2.9%)

UK Construction Output Vol YY (Apr) -3.3% (Prev. -4.9%)

UK Goods Trade Balance GBP (Apr) -14.03B vs. Exp. -11.25B (Prev. -12.29B, Rev. -12.0B)

EU/UK/US

Italian Finance Minister Tria has stated that the new government is ‘clear and unanimous’ with its plan to keep the nation inside the EUR. (FT)

Switzerland voted in referendum against motion to abolish traditional banking and only permitting money created by SNB; as expected. (Newswires)

Greece officials said plans for a Greek debt issuance could be knocked back following thee political uncertainty that occurred in Italy, according to press reports. (Times)

EQUITIES

European bourses are largely positive (Euro stoxx 50 +0.6%) ahead of US President Trump’s meeting with Kim Jong Un in Singapore. The UK’s FTSE 100 (+0.8%) outperforms other core bourses on GBP losses following weak industrial production and trade data. Italy’s FTSE MIB (+2.2%) is being buoyed by Italian bank stocks (FTSE Italia Bank index +4.2%) that are benefitting from comments by the Italian Finance Minister Tria who stated that the new government is ‘clear and unanimous’ with its plan to keep the nation inside the EUR. Rolls Royce are down 1% amid reports of further job cuts and more checks for their Trent engines. Daimler are also down about a percent after the KBA found 5 “illegal switch off devices” in their car engines and as US President Trump suggested that the US was again looking at tariffs on autos.

FX

USD: The broad Dollar is pretty mixed in the aftermath of the weekend G-7 gathering that ended in discord and President Trump disassociating the US from the official communique amidst accusations of dishonesty and deceit between himself and Canadian PM Trudeau. The DXY is on a modestly softer footing as a result, but rangebound and off m-t-d lows around 93.200 within 93.360-540 parameters ahead of CPI data and the FOMC.

JPY/CAD: Marked underperformers, with the Jpy seeing stops vs the Usd tripped and another test of resistance around 110.00, but the pair pulling back before the 200 DMA (110.18) amidst reports of supply in Jpy crosses at big figure levels (ie 130.00 vs the Eur) via market contacts. Meanwhile, the Loonie re-tested 1.3000 lows vs its US counterpart in wake of the aforementioned G7 spat as Trudeau called US tariff proposals insulting and Trump retorted by refusing to back the joint statement and claimed his Canadian host had stabbed the US in the back. The pair has retreated since towards 1.2955, but is still 0.4% or so higher alongside Usd/Mxn around 20.3500 even though Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo still has high hopes of a NAFTA deal.

GBP: Dire UK data in the form of ip, manufacturing/construction output and trade has dragged Cable back down below 1.3400 after the pair stopped just a few ticks shy of its 30 DMA at 1.3444, while Eur/Gbp has rebounded towards 0.8825.

EUR: The top G10 performer and back around 1.1800 vs the Greenback ahead of respective Fed and ECB policy meetings this week, with another FOMC hike virtually priced in and expectations turning more hawkish for the latter after recent sourced reports and official comments.

AUD/NZD: The Aud has managed to reclaim 0.7600+ status vs the Usd on hopes of something positive from the US-NK summit, but with trading volumes thinned by the Australian public holiday overnight, while the Kiwi is also holding relative gains vs the Dollar above 0.7000 as the Aud/Nzd cross hovers just over 1.0800.

CHF: Not much net reaction to the weekend rejection of radical changes to Swiss banking rules regarding credit, which was widely anticipated, as the Franc trades relatively flat vs the Usd circa 0.9860 and weaker vs the perky Eur with the cross over 1.1600.

NOK/TRY: Both weaker after data, but not for the same reasons as Eur/Nok crossed 9.5000 to the upside on weaker than forecast Norwegian inflation ahead of next week’s Norges Bank policy meeting, while the Lira fell in wake of the latest daily Usd swap auction that drew significantly more bids than on Friday – Usd/Try back up over 4.5000.

FIXED INCOME

An almost complete set of weak data has seen Short Sterling futures reverse earlier losses, while Gilts got to within just 1 tick of parity at 121.81 having been 42 ticks underwater at one stage, as already low BoE tightening prospects take another knock. Elsewhere, Bunds have also pared some lost ground, but more on the inverse-correlation between core Eurozone and Italian/peripheral paper as the latter retreat further from lofty peaks (10 year BTP now around 150 ticks ahead vs 320 ticks at best). US Treasuries remain in bear-steepening mode ahead of major data/events in the form of CPI, Trump-Kim and the FOMC meeting, and with a double-dose of supply looming today (3 and 10 year notes totalling USD 54bln).

COMMODITIES

Oil prices are slipping, with the WTI and Brent crude futures both down over USD 0.70, pressured by rising US drilling activity, increasing Russian output to 11.1mln BPD in June and Saudi Arabia reportedly increasing oil production by 100k in June ahead of incoming sanctions on Iran. Gold is currently negative on the day (-0.15%) as markets await news from the Trump-Kim summit. Copper is negative for the second straight session as supply concerns start to ease.

Russia's oil output at 11.1mln bpd in the first week of June, according to sources. (Interfax)

Saudi Arabia is producing 100k bpd more than last month and plans to raise output again by at least that amount. (WSJ)

subject: ING on UK data: sharp fall in manufacturing casts doubt over economic recovery
content: • While our feeling is that policymakers want to lift rates again over coming months given the better wage growth trend, these growth risks mean a summer rate hike is far from guaranteed. If the economy continues to show only limited signs of recovery, then the Bank may well opt to remain on hold in August. As a few BoE voters have said recently, the cost of waiting to raise rates is not especially high.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

11th June 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week somewhat cautious ahead of the upcoming key risk events including the summit between US and North Korea tomorrow, as well as the FOMC and ECB policy meetings later this week. Furthermore, a market closure in Australia and the G7 fall out in which Trump refused to endorse the communique and criticized Canadian PM Trudeau as being dishonest and weak, also added to the tentative tone and saw US equity futures briefly pressured at the open. However, US equity futures have since recovered, while both Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) and KOSPI (+0.6%) were marginally positive as focus turned towards the upcoming historical Trump-Kim summit. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) were mixed with underperformance in mainland China after inaction by the PBoC led to a liquidity drain and as participants digested mixed inflation data. Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat amid the tentative tone in the region and a lack of Rinban announcement by the BoJ.

FTSE

UK Broadcasters – BBC, ITV (ITV LN) and Channel 4 have agreed to collaborate and invest in GBP 125mln in Freeview to combat Netflix and Amazon. (FT)

UK Gambling names – Swiss voters have supported a bill that will block foreign betting sites. (BBC)

Persimmon (PSN LN) – The co. is facing a legal challenge over the GBP 75mln bonus paid to Jeff Fairburn and other directors. (Times)

Sky (SKY LN) – EU regulators are set to clear Comcast’s bid for the Co. without conditions, according to reports. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co.’s Tagrisso has received EU approval for treatment of patients with a form of lung cancer. (Newswires)

Rolls Royce (RR/ LN) – The co. is set to announce 4,000 more job cuts this week, with the co. aiming to cut costs in middle-management positions. (Guardian)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Inmarsat (ISAT LN) – Co. has confirmed and rejected a non-bind proposal from Echostar Corp. (Newswires)

RENTOKIL (RTO LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

OCADO (OCDO LN) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM UNDERPERFORM AT BERNSTEIN

ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) – The co. has reportedly considered a sale of its shipbuilding unit, as according to an internally circulated note. Elsewhere Elliott has critiqued the co. over its JV with Tata Steel. (Newswires)

DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: US President Trump refused to endorse the G7 communique which he stated was due to false statements made by Canadian PM Trudeau
content:
US President Trump refused to endorse the G7 communique which he stated was due to false statements made by Canadian PM Trudeau

Asian equity markets and the USD subsequently began the week somewhat cautiously

Looking ahead, highlights include Norwegian CPI, UK production, Barnier & Davis meet, US 3 and 10yr supply

G7/Trade

G7 official communique which was backed by all countries apart from the US, acknowledged free, fair and mutually beneficial trade was a vital engine for growth and jobs, while the countries will strive to lower tariff barriers and subsidies, as well as continue fighting protectionism. (Newswires)

US President Trump refused to endorse the G7 communique which he stated was due to false statements made by Canadian PM Trudeau who he criticized as being dishonest and weak, while he also suggested the US is looking at tariffs on autos flooding the market. This was in response to comments from Canadian PM Trudeau that Canada would impose retaliatory tariffs against US and warned that Canada would not be pushed around. (Twitter/Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted overnight about Canada and Trudeau in which he suggested Canada was bragging about making USD 100bln in trade from US and that PM Trudeau acts hurt when called out regarding this. US President also commented that Germany pays 1% of GDP to NATO while US pays 4% of a much larger GDP to NATO which he suggested doesn't make sense, while he added that US protects Europe but gets clobbered on trade and that change is coming. Furthermore, Trump also tweeted he will not let friends and enemies take advantage anymore regarding trade and that the American worker must be put first. (Twitter)

German Chancellor Merkel said have agreed with the US to review trade ties and tariffs, while she added that the aim is to avoid US tariffs on autos. Merkel further stated that EU will reassess if US imposes auto tariffs and that they must seek own path if negotiations fail, while she also commented that EU has prepared counter measures against US tariffs on steel and aluminium. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week somewhat cautious ahead of the upcoming key risk events including the summit between US and North Korea tomorrow, as well as the FOMC and ECB policy meetings later this week. Furthermore, a market closure in Australia and the G7 fall out in which Trump refused to endorse the communique and criticized Canadian PM Trudeau as being dishonest and weak, also added to the tentative tone and saw US equity futures briefly pressured at the open. However, US equity futures have since recovered, while both Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) and KOSPI (+0.6%) were marginally positive as focus turned towards the upcoming historical Trump-Kim summit. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) were mixed with underperformance in mainland China after inaction by the PBoC led to a liquidity drain and as participants digested mixed inflation data. Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat amid the tentative tone in the region and a lack of Rinban announcement by the BoJ.

Chinese CPI (May) M/M -0.2% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. -0.2%). (Newswires)
Chinese CPI (May) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.8%)
Chinese PPI (May) Y/Y 4.1% vs. Exp. 3.9% (Prev. 3.4%)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 20bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4064 (Prev. 6.4003)


UK/EU

Switzerland voted in referendum against motion to abolish traditional banking and only permitting money created by SNB; as expected. (Newswires)

Greece officials said plans for a Greek debt issuance could be knocked back following thee political uncertainty that occurred in Italy, according to press reports. (Times)

Italian Finance Minister Tria has stated that the new government is ‘clear and unanimous’ with its plan to keep the nation inside the EUR. (FT)


Fitch affirmed Poland at A-, outlook stable. DBRS affirmed Germany at AAA, stable trend and affirmed Poland at A, Stable trend. (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, the DXY was slightly softer after Trump alienated the US from its closest allies by refusing to endorse a joint G7 statement and warned of auto tariffs, while he also took to Twitter in his reproach against PM Trudeau and to a lesser extent the EU. This benefitted the greenback’s major counterparts in which EUR/USD attempted to reclaim the 1.1800 handle and with GBP/USD above 1.3400, while antipodeans were also higher but with price action across the majors mostly contained ahead of the looming risk events. Elsewhere, there were initial safe-haven flows seen into JPY which was later fully reversed, while USD/CAD was short-squeezed at the open as CAD took the brunt of the G7 disarray and Trump’s overzealous tweeting.


COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight with WTI crude futures slightly lower and stuck within a narrow trading range amid a lack of fresh drivers for energy. Elsewhere, copper was subdued amid a somewhat cautious tone and gold was uneventful around the USD 1300/oz level with participants tentative ahead of this week’s policy decisions from both the Fed and ECB, while silver outperformed as prices retested last week’s highs to print its best levels in 7 weeks.

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (8 Jun) 1062 (Prev. 1060). (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia reportedly increased oil production by 100k in June ahead of incoming sanctions on Iran. (WSJ)


GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump and North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un arrived in Singapore ahead of the summit on Tuesday. (ABC)

US President Trump stated that he believes North Korean Leader Kim will do something positive and added that he has one time shot but thinks it will go well. Elsewhere, President Trump stated some of the other G7 members agreed with his view that having Russia back in the group would be positive. (Newswires)

North Korea said summit with US will discuss permanent and firm peace regime, as well as denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula. (KCNA)


US

Treasuries were pretty much unchanged on Friday as investors have been cautiously awaiting for a G7 outcome and ahead of FOMC and ECB next week. Most of the action was concentrated in the front end of the curve though yields were lower by less than c.1bps. Spreads were mixed, 2s10s were wider by c.1bps at settlement. US 10YR T-notes futures (Sep 2018) were unchanged at 119-19.

White House Chief of Staff Kelly reportedly told some senators last week that the White House was a miserable place to work. (Hill/NYT)
